awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Research Challenges of Identifying Integer Sequences Using the OEIS
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides support for REU Site: Research Challenges of Identifying Integer Sequences Using the OEIS, at Muhlenberg College.  Projects make an effective use the On-line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences (OEIS) as a resource tool, and provide glimpses into future.  The research impact of the OEIS across disciplines continues to grow. Applications of the  to the life sciences, physical sciences, and earth sciences abound. The OEIS has also impacted research in scientific and engineering fields beyond the mathematical sciences. There are currently more than 3,000 papers and books in many areas of mathematics, computer science, and many other branches of science that reference and/or acknowledge the OEIS. The large number of citations and links to OEIS attests to its impact on advancing many areas of active research and its appeal to a broad multidisciplinary community. 

The intellectual focus of this research concentrates on the important role sequences play in mathematics, as well as their contributions to other fields. The program will contribute to the OEIS knowledge base through projects that are influenced by recent developments and tackle challenges of mathematical and scientific discovery inspired by integer sequences. These challenges include experimentation by developing computational algorithms and meta-algorithms through the use of computers. The methodologies applied to these challenges have come to be loosely defined as "rigorous experimental mathematics" and have proven effective in developing conjectures in areas that include number theory, algorithmic and enumerative combinatorics, combinatorial number theory, and many other mathematical fields. Our program aims to prepare students to become the next generation of mathematical scientists efficient in researching sequences and their applications through the OEIS database, the most successful of whom will have the capacity to look to the OEIS for inspiration. We will nurture this capacity by highlighting the contributions to the mathematical sciences of the On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences. A particular emphasis of our program will be to discuss the important role the OEIS has played in developing conjectures in areas that include number theory, algorithmic and enumerative combinatorics, combinatorial number theory, and many other mathematical and scientific fields, as well as the tools necessary for identifying such conjectures.

por.por_cntn:
The Muhlenberg College Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program prepares participants to be part of the next generation of mathematical scientists, the most successful of whom will have the capacity to look both within and beyond the confines of the mathematical sciences for inspiration. Our program nurtures this capacity by introducing undergraduates to the research impact of the On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences (OEIS). The program aims to ?publicize the OEIS among a cadre of students and early-career researchers to help establish it as a tool in their ?research arsenal.?? Establishing the OEIS as a ?tool in the research arsenal? of undergraduate students will encourage continuing their education into graduate school and help train the next generation of OEIS database users. We achieve this goal by involving mentors from different areas of the mathematical sciences, by integrating activities with nearby related industries, and by leveraging Muhlenberg College?s position within the Lehigh Valley Association of Independent Colleges (LVAIC). In addition to students funded by this NSF grant, the Muhlenberg College REU program includes independently funded students that enhances the cultural diversity and educational impact of the program.

The broader impacts of our Research Experiences for Undergraduates program come from informing students about their future education and career choices. Participation in research projects gives them the confidence and grounding to pursue and succeed in these choices. Our program enriches students by exposing them to varied perspectives offered by different cultures and by theory and application. Applications of the OEIS to the life sciences, physical sciences, and earth sciences abound. There are currently more than 3,500 papers and books in many areas of mathematics (especially number theory, combinatorics, and discrete mathematics), computer science, engineering, physics, and many other branches of science that reference and/or acknowledge the OEIS. The large number of citations and links to OEIS attests to its impact on advancing many areas of active research and its appeal to a broad community. The OEIS has also impacted research in scientific and engineering fields beyond the mathematical sciences. Searching through the OEIS ?offers glimpses into some of the far-flung areas of mathematics and science that are prolific generators of integer sequences.?

The intellectual focus of the research concentrates on the important role sequences play in number theory, combinatorics, and discrete mathematics, as well as their contributions to other fields. This program contributes to the OEIS knowledge base through projects that are influenced by recent developments and tackle challenges of mathematical discovery inspired by integer sequences. These challenges include experimentation by developing computational algorithms and meta-algorithms through the use of computers. The methodologies developed through these projects have come to be loosely defined as ?rigorous experimental mathematics? and have proven effective in developing conjectures in areas that include number theory, algorithmic and enumerative combinatorics, combinatorial number theory, and many other mathematical fields.

The scientific output of the students work can be seen in numerous publications of their original research in scientific journals and conference proceedings, new sequences additional contributed to the OEIS and additional information to existing sequences in the OEIS, and conference presentations. For example, REU 2016 participants Thomas Brazelton (Johns Hopkins University), Siddarth Kannan (Pomona College), and Matthew Litman (Pennsylvania State University), mentored by Joshua Harrington (Cedar Crest College), published their work ?On consecutive primitive nth roots of unity modulo q,? in the Journal of Number Theory, and presented their results at the 2017 Joint Mathematics Meeting in Atlanta. 2018 REU participants Sierra Brown (Creighton University), Spencer Daugherty (Mount Holyoke College), Barbara Maldonado (University of Houston), Sean Rainville (Plymouth State University), and Riley Waechter (Northern Arizona University), mentored by Eugene Fiorini (Muhlenberg College) and Tony Wong (Kutztown University), published five new sequences in the OEIS (A316533, A316629, A316632, A316781, and A317367) related to their research on Nimbers of Node-Kayles games on families of infinite graphs. This research was also presented at the 2019 Joint Mathematics Meeting in Baltimore and is being prepared for publication.

For most student participants in this program, this was their first introduction to a research environment in which they worked on open-ended problems that do not have a clear pathway to a predetermined solution. Most of our participants have gone onto, or are planning on going to, graduate school. Many of them cite the Muhlenberg College undergraduate research experience as a determining factor in their decision and in their preparedness for graduate school. Participants have consistently reported in their end-of-program surveys satisfaction with their experience in the program, particularly regarding their research mentor. Participants also indicated a great deal of involvement with research projects, and felt their undergraduate research experience influenced the likelihood of pursuing a PhD and getting a job related to the mathematical sciences.
